content:
In traditional "pen and paper" mathematics, the following inductive construction:

inductive InductivelyDefined
| zero : InductivelyDefined
| successor : InductivelyDefined → InductivelyDefined

Would be viewed as requiring the minimal axioms for "inductively defined sets" (or inductive data types).

Lean shows:

#print axioms InductivelyDefined
-- 'InductivelyDefined' does not depend on any axioms

-- And also:
#print axioms Nat
-- 'Nat' does not depend on any axioms
theorem t : 1 + 1 = 2 := by rfl
#print axioms t
-- 't' does not depend on any axioms

If someone is familiar with the usual axioms of mathematics but not with Lean or type theory, how can I convert the statement "does not depend on any axioms" to a more familiar statement about "does not depend on any additional axiomatic assumptions needed beyond Lean’s built-in type-theoretic framework, which roughly corresponds to the following axioms we are used to in traditional mathematics: construction of inductively defined sets, …, …, etc.".

In other words, how do I explain Lean’s "base set of implicit axioms" in a way that connects naturally to the usual axioms taught in standard undergraduate mathematics courses? (Accepting that full rigor would require a deeper dive into type theory, which might be too advanced for an undergraduate audience.)

When you write down

inductive InductivelyDefined
| zero : InductivelyDefined
| successor : InductivelyDefined → InductivelyDefined

you get four things for free, that don't depend on any axioms and don't have any definition:

  • You get InductivelyDefined : Type

  • You get the constructors, which is how you make your type
    InductivelyDefined.zero : InductivelyDefined and
    InductivelyDefined.successor : InductivelyDefined → InductivelyDefined

  • You get the recursor, which lets you do pattern-matching recursion
    InductivelyDefined.rec.{u} : {motive : InductivelyDefined → Sort u} → motive InductivelyDefined.zero → ((a : InductivelyDefined) → motive a → motive a.successor) → (t : InductivelyDefined) → motive t

  • You get the reduction rules, which let you compute
    InductivelyDefined.rec zero successor InductivelyDefined.zero ≡ zero and
    InductivelyDefined.rec zero successor (InductivelyDefined.succ a) ≡ successor a (InductivelyDefined.rec zero successor a)

@Aaron Liu That is a good summary regarding the implementation details, but what I think I'm looking for is a mapping between the output of "#print axioms […]" and the traditional axioms familiar to undergraduate mathematics. For example, something along these lines:

  • If you see the output “[…]”, then you are (roughly speaking) not assuming more than, say, what corresponds to a limited set theory that allows for inductively defined sets.
  • If you see the output “[…]”, then you are (roughly speaking) assuming no more than standard Zermelo–Fraenkel set theory (ZF).
  • If you see the output “[…]”, then you are (roughly speaking) assuming no more than Zermelo–Fraenkel set theory along with the axiom of choice (ZFC).
  • Etc.

In particular, I’m interested in this mapping for the "base assumptions" that are implicit in a "no assumption" statement like "Nat does not depend on any axioms".
So to be clear, for each of the 8 subsets of the three core axioms in Lean, you want to find a traditional theory which is approximately equiconsistent with Lean+that subset?

#leantt says that full Lean is consistent relative to ZFC + {"there are n inaccessible cardinals" | for n < ω\omegaω}. That's surely overkill for answering the base set of implicit axioms, but it's not a wrong answer for what to say when #print axioms says "does not depend on any axioms".

If Classical.choice isn't used, I have no idea if it's ZF instead of ZFC. Does your audience appreciate the finer details of ZFC well enough to care whether or not choice is used?

@Niels Voss Yes, if possible -- that would be the dream answer. I expect that some of the eight cases might naturally cluster together, assuming we're referring to the eight subsets of {propext, Classical.choice, Quot.sound}.

To avoid things about inaccessible cardinals, I believe you have to check what universe levels appear in a term. Recursors immediately jump up to higher universes (and thus a need for inaccessible cardinals), but if you treat recursors as being families of functions, one per concrete motive (supplied as a formula), then I think you can avoid them, so long as everything else stays within Type.
Without choice, Lean doesn't have the Law of the Excluded Middle. I think this makes it less powerful in some ways than even ZF, although I'm not too good at logic so I might be wrong.

Lean's Classical.choice is also slightly stronger than the traditional axiom of choice: it corresponds to the Axiom of Global Choice. For some reason this doesn't seem to make a difference when comparing the consistency of Lean and ZFC + n large cardinals for any finite n

Unfortunately, I don't know how propext and Quot.sound affect Lean's strength. If I remember correctly, you can create quotient types using the traditional approach using equivalence classes, which removes the need for Quot.sound. (I think you need Classical.choice for something and propext to show the extensionality property for sets). Of course, this quotient will have really bad computational properties, which is why we don't do this.

(I think you need Classical.choice for something and propext to show the extensionality property for sets). Of course, this quotient will have really bad computational properties, which is why we don't do this.

You need Quot.sound to prove that equivalence classes are extensional (if you implement them as docs#Set).
Oh right that's because function extensionality is proved using quotients
If we assumed function extensionality as an axiom, could we have created equivalence classes using that?

Before starting this thread, my initial, naive mapping was as follows:

  • 't' does not depend on any axioms: This can be interpreted roughly as “t does not rely on any axioms beyond those in standard Zermelo–Fraenkel set theory (ZF).”
  • t depends on axioms: [propext], or t depends on axioms: [Quot.sound]: These cases are treated similarly to the above—they do not introduce anything extra that we would consider axioms in traditional mathematics (beyond ZF).
  • t depends on axioms: [Classical.choice]: This can be read roughly as “t does not depend on any axioms beyond those in standard Zermelo–Fraenkel set theory with the axiom of choice (ZFC).”

Viewed from the perspective of traditional mathematics, this effectively makes the mapping into the following:

  • Any #print axioms output not mentioning Classical.choice: think "ZF"
  • Any #print axioms output mentioning Classical.choice: think "ZFC"
Without Classical.choice you don't get em so maybe IZF (intuitionistic ZF)?

@Aaron Liu I'm likely missing something, but isn't any use of le (law of excluded middle) properly reported as depending on the axiom Classical.choice?

import Mathlib
theorem t (P : Prop) : P ∨ ¬P := by exact Classical.em P
#print axioms t
-- 't' depends on axioms: [propext, Classical.choice, Quot.sound]
-- Diaconescu's theorem: excluded middle from choice, Function extensionality and propositional extensionality.
I mean that ZF is usually including em but without Classical.choice you don't get em

Ah, yes to be precise I guess one would need to specify the choices:

  1. Use of set-theoretic axioms:
  • ZF (Zermelo-Fraenkel) without the axiom of choice
  • ZFC (ZF with the axiom of choice)
  1. Use of underlying logical systems:
  • Classical logic (which includes the law of excluded middle)
  • Intuitionistic logic (which rejects the law of excluded middle)

Thus we obtain four distinct frameworks:

  • Classical ZF: ZF set theory formulated in classical logic.
  • Classical ZFC: ZF with the axiom of choice, formulated in classical logic.
  • Intuitionistic ZF (IZF): an intuitionistic version of ZF where the underlying logic is constructive.
  • Intuitionistic ZFC: an intuitionistic version of ZF with the axiom of choice (is that even a thing?).

Of which "Classical ZFC" and "Intuitionistic ZF" are the two alternatives of relevance here I guess.
it turns out that choice implies LEM, so intuitionistic ZFC is the same as Classical ZFC...
although i guess this is only "the same" in the sense that the same theorems can be proven, not that the proofs are the same
Thanks! (Further reading for the curious: Diaconescu's theorem, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diaconescu%27s_theorem)

I don't have a proof, but my suspicion is that lean with no axioms is also equiconsistent to ZFC with countably many inaccessible cardinals. ZF and ZFC are known to be equiconsistent since Goedel and Cohen, and most of the actual "power" of the theory comes from the ability to define very big inductive types like docs#PSet, and impredicativity of Prop, neither of which involves axioms. LEM is also known not to raise consistency strength in many cases, e.g. heyting arithmetic is equiconsistent with peano arithmetic, and IIRC IZF is equiconsistent with ZF.
propext for sure doesn't do anything to consistency strength, and Quot.sound is something you can work around using setoids
Thanks a lot @Mario Carneiro!

As I understand it "consistency strength" gauges how "safe" a theory is from contradictions, while "proof strength" measures the range of theorems it can prove. Two theories are said to be "equiconsistent" if the absence of contradictions in one guarantees the absence in the other, even if they prove different results. Sounds about right?

Am I right in understanding that IZF (Intuitionistic ZF), ZF, ZFC, and ZF+GC (Zermelo–Fraenkel set theory with Global Choice) are all equiconsistent—that is, if one of them is consistent, then so are the others—but that they differ in proof-theoretic strength/"provability strength" in the following order from weakest to strongest:

  • IZF: Intuitionistic ZF is proof-theoretically weaker than classical ZF because it is formulated using intuitionistic logic, which does not assume the law of excluded middle. Concretely, in IZF we cannot prove P∨¬PP∨¬PP∨¬P for an arbitrary proposition PPP.
  • ZF: Zermelo–Fraenkel set theory without the axiom of choice is proof-theoretically weaker than ZFC since it lacks the axiom that guarantees every set can be well-ordered (a set is said to be well-ordered if it is equipped with a total order such that every nonempty subset has a least element). Concretely, in ZF we cannot prove that set of real numbers is well-ordered, since doing so would require an ordering in which every nonempty subset of the reals has a smallest element—a result that depends on the axiom of choice.
  • ZFC: Although ZFC is proof-theoretically stronger than ZF due to its inclusion of the axiom of choice, it is still weaker than ZF+GC because it does not assume global choice. Concretely, while ZFC proves that every set (including the real numbers) can be well-ordered, it does not provide a single, uniform, and definable well-ordering of the entire universe of sets. In other words, there is no fixed formula in ZFC that orders every set in a canonical way
  • ZF+GC: This system is the proof-theoretically strongest among those listed, as it extends ZF with the Global Choice axiom, thereby providing a uniform, definable well-ordering of the universe.
yes
Although I think people often use "proof strength" to also refer to consistency strength. I would say that ZF is not conservative over IZF

Thanks a lot Mario for taking the time to sharing your knowledge. TIL about "conservative" in this context. "A is not conservative over B" means there exists at least one statement in the shared language that A proves but B does not.
